ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

UNOCCUPIED HDB FLATS
(Conversion into tourist accommodation)


    1. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for National Development, in view of the current shortage of hotel rooms, whether the Housing and Development Board will consider the possibility of (i) converting unoccupied flats into rooms for tourists' occupation, and (ii) allowing flat owners who have spare bedrooms to let them out for short stay by tourists.

     The Senior Minister of State for National Development (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, most of the unoccupied HDB flats are 3-room flats in Woodlands. Some of these flats are being converted into bigger flats to meet the new demand of Singaporeans. HDB has no plans to convert them into tourist accommodation. If an organisation, such as a hotel, supported by the Singapore Tourist Promotion Board, is able to come up with a feasible and workable proposal for converting entire vacant blocks to be used as interim tourist accommodation, my Ministry would be prepared to consider the idea.

    Sir, as to whether my Ministry would be prepared to allow bed-and-breakfast operations in HDB flats, it must be noted that such operations in other countries are conducted in landed properties. Allowing bed-and-breakfast operations in high-rise apartments can cause disamenity to other residents. The HDB will therefore take a cautious approach in considering any such proposal. Its priority is to provide housing to citizens and it must ensure that the residential ambience and security of HDB estates would not be compromised. My Ministry would only be prepared to consider such a proposal if a single responsible organisation, such as the Singapore Tourist Promotion Board, is able to work out a feasible and comprehensive proposal on how this can be done without causing disamenity to the community.

     Mr Teo Chong Tee (Changi): Sir, may I ask the Senior Minister of State whether, besides Woodlands, there are vacant units of flats available in large numbers in the eastern part of Singapore?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Sir, there are other vacant flats scattered here and there throughout the island but they are not in large enough numbers to warrant such an application.

TRADE WITH EASTERN BLOC COUNTRIES
(Assistance to local traders)


    2. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Trade and Industry what plans his Ministry has to help local traders to export to or to trade with the Eastern bloc countries; and whether there are any plans to open trade offices in or send local trade missions to these countries.

Column: 565



     The Minister of State for Trade and Industry (Mr Mah Bow Tan) (for the Minister for Trade and Industry): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Eastern bloc has hitherto not been a major trading partner of Singapore. In 1989, trade with them amounted to S$1.13 billion, which is less than 1% of our global trade. However, in the medium to long term, following the recent political and economic developments in the Eastern bloc, this trade should increase.

    The Trade Development Board has been actively promoting trade with the Eastern bloc for several years. It has organised trade missions to these countries, and participated in trade fairs there, on an annual basis since 1966, and then twice a year since 1988. For 1990, TDB is planning to send three missions and to participate in three trade fairs. These will cover USSR as well as almost all the East European countries. TDB is currently also studying setting up more trade offices in Eastern Europe.

    TDB tries to bring together Singapore traders and trading organisations from these countries to form joint venture trading companies. These will match the marketing expertise and the connections of Singapore traders with the needs of consumers and firms in Eastern Europe. In the last two years, nine such joint ventures have been established.

MAIN AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES OF SINGAPORE FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR

    Head Q (cont.) -

    Resumption of Debate on Question [20th March, 1990],

    "That the sum to be allocated for Head Q be reduced by $10 in respect of Code QC 1500 of the Main Estimates." - [Dr Ho Tat Kin].

    Question again proposed.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Sir, when we adjourned yesterday, several speakers have spoken

Column: 566

under this item and we did not have a chance to reply. I propose to do so now. The matters raised by Dr Wong Kwei Cheong on touting and Encik Yatiman on the Woodlands Checkpoint will be dealt with by my colleague, the Senior Minister of State. I propose to deal with the other points.

    On the points raised by Dr Ho Tat Kin on illegal parking, the strategy adopted by the Traffic Police is two-pronged - first, persuasion, public awareness and public education and, secondly, strict enforcement measures. Besides public education, enforcement has indeed been stepped up. In 1988, 172,000 summonses were issued for illegal parking. This figure increased by 17% in 1989. The number of vehicles towed away last year was 4,243 compared to 1,555 in 1988. Besides towing away of illegally parked vehicles, other measures which have been resorted to are increasing the fines for illegal parking, increasing the fines for towing away of vehicles and for storage of illegally parked vehicles.

    I agree with the Member that there should be stiffer punishments for cars which deliberately obstruct the flow of traffic and in this regard the Traffic Police is paying special attention to this matter. They will step up the measure of towing away, particularly where an illegally parked vehicle obstructs traffic, especially in busy thoroughfares.

    As for clamping device, unfortunately, this can only be used under certain circumstances, such as a confined area, because if it is used on a busy street, even though a car is parked illegally, it does not enable the car to be removed quickly to facilitate traffic. Between use of clamp and towing away for busy thoroughfares, towing away is a better measure.

    I would like to inform him that the Traffic Police is also considering demerit points for illegal parking, especially for those who repeat the offence.

    Mr Loh Meng See asked about the procedures in our legislation which perhaps may be outdated in regard to references to various categories of offences. He is indeed right. The Criminal Procedure Code

Column: 567

was drawn up in 1955. Some of the provisions are archaic. In fact, until recently, we even had provisions referring to information to be given to penghulus. There are also provisions which restrict certain powers to police officers of a certain rank or above certain ranks, such as sergeant and above. This is understandable because in the early days when junior police officers were not well educated or we did not have enough well-educated police officers they had to be closely supervised and certain powers had to be exercised only by the supervisors.

    However, Police has gone through a transformation and now junior police officers are better trained and educated. These restrictions that exist in the statute are outdated, unnecessary and, in fact, in some instances, they actually impede the exercise of police functions. For example, the Commissioner of Police now entrusts to certain selected officers the task of investigation. They are called assistant investigating officers and they have investigative tasks.

    To give you one example. The Criminal Procedure Code provides that when a search for anything is conducted in the premises in respect of any offence and a thing is capable of being concealed on a person, only a police officer of or above the rank of a sergeant is empowered to search the person in the premises. Therefore, although an assistant investigating officer who is below the rank of a sergeant has the power to search the premises he does not have the power to search persons found in the premises. Obviously, the disadvantage is that he can have disposal of evidence in the premises. These and other aspects of the Criminal Procedure Code will be looked into in the light of changing conditions in the Police Force.

    Mr Chiam See Tong, I think, saw some sinister purpose in the security screening personnel in the airport. Let me assure him that the security screening personnel at the airport are to conduct security screening of all pre-board passengers and their luggage. They are checked for arms, weapons, explosives, to make sure that these are not brought into the plane, whether they are Singapore passengers or

Column: 568

foreign passengers. In fact, this is a very strict requirement insisted on by the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) as a measure for the safety and security of international flights.

    The additional manpower of 138 personnel which he referred to is because there is going to be a new terminal II. With the new terminal, you need additional security screening personnel.

    Mr Chiam See Tong also asked about better deployment of personnel for crime control and he referred to certain indicators in the Budget book. Let me, in fact, assure him that the total number of seizable offences, ie, offences that the police can arrest without a warrant, although it has shown a slight increase since 1980, serious seizable offences, ie, murder, robbery, housebreaking, rape, outraging of modesty and so on, in 1983 the annual rate was 33.8%. But from 1986 onwards, the rate of increase in seizable crimes has been brought under control. In 1989, there was in fact a decrease in these selected seizable offences compared with 1988. For total seizable offences, there was a 8.2% decrease in 1989.

    I might add, Sir, that we compare well with other countries such as Japan and Hong Kong in having a lower number of major crimes per hundred thousand population. Singapore's figure of 228 major crimes in 1987 is in fact even lower when we compare with cities like London which has 3,423 major crimes per hundred thousand population.

    Finally, I should also say that when it comes to deployment of police personnel, of the 7,000 regular policemen that we have in the Police Force, between 68% and 70% are in fact deployed for front-line policing, ie, coming into contact with members of the public.

    As for Dr Lee Siew-Choh, I do not intend to repeat everything I have said regarding his comments on internal security because we have had in the past few months questions by him on abolition of ISA, and from Mr Chiam See Tong on whether for the 25th anniversary we can relax matters. All these are repetitions of the same thing. Chia Thye Poh - will he be released?

Column: 569

Since I have given full answers to these questions raised in recent months it does not make any point for me to repeat them. But I would like to remind Dr Lee Siew-Choh that Chia Thye Poh is not a political detainee. He has been released on certain conditions to Sentosa Island. In fact, Dr Lee Siew-Choh visited him and, according to the Chinese press, he spent some time with him. And there was a photograph of both of them smiling very happily.

    Dr Lee wants me to disclose the operational and financial details of our internal security agency. It will be foolhardy for me to do so as this would jeopardise our national security. Because such disclosures will expose the capability, the extent of resources, the modus operandi of our investigative agencies to undesirable and subversive elements as well as to hostile foreign agencies. Therefore, it will seriously undermine our effectiveness in meeting threats to subversion and internal security.

    Dr Lee then spoke of police violence, painting a scenario of total lawlessness in our Police Force. I think that is very unfair. It is absolutely important that every police officer be of the highest integrity and complies with the law and police procedures. Both the Police and the Ministry of Home Affairs in fact take a very serious view of any instance or allegation of infraction of the law or disregarding of police procedures. I know, because I have discussed with the Commissioner of Police. The Commissioner of Police takes a personal interest in such matters because it affects the image of the whole Force. But the Police organisation is a large organisation - 7,000 regulars, 3,000 full-time National Servicemen and 16,000 reservists. It is inevitable that there may be one or two black sheep. But what is important is that if any police officer is a black sheep and he commits a breach of the law or violates police procedures, whether it is bribery, corruption, or allegation of assault, it is important that our system is such that the matter is fully investigated and, when substantiated, he is brought to book. Either he is charged in Court or he is disciplined and dismissed. I think Members know it. They

Column: 570

read it in the papers sometimes. The dismissed police officers in fact sometimes go to the MP to appeal. But that is the best deterrent.

    Dr Lee Siew-Choh then went on to raise the point about traffic lights. I am afraid his speech came four days late because we had a debate on traffic lights under the Ministry of National Development. Let me say: let's be thankful that the system is working smoothly. I am told that of more than 1,000 junctions with traffic lights, the number of malfunctioning lights averages about only three a day. Then he wants traffic policemen to be stationed at all traffic light junctions. This is absurd. The total number of traffic police officers is just 543 and there are over 1,000 traffic light junctions. It will be labour-intensive and unnecessary. But the Traffic Police is always alerted to deploy its men to manually control traffic whenever there is a traffic jam or black-out. In fact, many people have told me that they are very impressed by the fact that when there is a traffic light malfunctioning or there is a black-out, almost immediately there are men at the scene to guide traffic.

    Sir, the other questions will be answered by my colleague, the Senior Minister of State.

     The Senior Minister of State for Home Affairs (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Sir, yesterday Dr Wong Kwei Cheong, hon. Member for Cairnhill, asked for a status report on the problem of touting along Orchard Road.

    Sir, I am pleased to inform Members that the new anti-touting law which came into effect on 9th June last year has provided a very effective means of dealing with the touting problem. A series of anti-touting operations were conducted between June last year up to 12th March this year, during which 140 touts were arrested and charged in Court. 58 of them pleaded guilty and were given jail sentences ranging from three weeks to four months and fines ranging from $1,000 to $5,000. The most severe punishment meted out was a four-month imprisonment term against a repeat offender. The rest of those arrested had claimed trial and their cases will be dealt with in due course.

Column: 571



    Sir, as a result of sustained police enforcement action, there has been a remarkable improvement along Orchard Road tourist belt. Touts no longer hang around the pedestrian mall annoying tourists and Singaporeans. Shops no longer openly display their counterfeit goods for public viewing. Most of the shops dealing in counterfeit watches have either closed down or stopped dealing in this illegal trade altogether.

    Sir, the touting situation is now firmly under control. Those shops previously dealing in counterfeit goods are being closely monitored and will be raided whenever there is any indication of them reverting to touting activities.

    Sir, I now come to Encik Yatiman Yusof's question. He asked about the redevelopment of the Woodlands Checkpoint. The Woodlands Checkpoint is being renovated at a total cost of $16.2 million to increase its handling capacity and also to provide better amenities for visitors to Singapore and also for Singaporeans who are leaving. When completed in May this year, the number of clearance lanes for cars and motorcycles will be increased from 36 to 48, and lanes for lorries from six to eight. Clearance counters catering to bus passengers will also be increased from 22 to 40.

    Other improvements will include air-conditioned clearance halls for the bus passengers, and this will also address the points raised by Encik Yatiman yesterday that we should provide better facilities to give a better impression, since this is the first point of entry for many visitors. Covered walkways will be provided for those who have to walk from one part to the other within the Checkpoint. Car-sensing devices will also be provided to have better control of the cars as they approach the various immigration clearance lanes. There will be a separate customs inspection area to avoid a bottleneck situation at the immigration car bay. And part of the improvement in amenities would be to have better and newer public toilets.

    Sir, the new facilities will be fully operational on 1st June. Once it is fully operational, clearance lanes that will be kept open each day will depend on the traffic

Column: 572

volume. Immigration Department will keep enough lanes open, especially during peak hours and public holidays, to ensure a smooth flow of traffic in and out of Singapore.

    Sir, to cater for the long-term growth of traffic, Immigration Department is drawing up plans for the development of a new Checkpoint. The Member asked yesterday what has happened to the resettlement of the squatters at Kampong Fatimah. The clearance of the squatters at Kampong Fatimah is part of this redevelopment plan. There will also be minor reclamation work along the shore-line to accommodate this new Checkpoint. The proposed Checkpoint is targeted for completion in six to seven years' time. It will then replace the existing Checkpoint.

     Dr Ho Tat Kin (Toa Payoh GRC): Sir, I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, I want to get a clarification from the Minister because he says ---

     The Chairman: The amendment has been withdrawn, Mr Chiam. Amendment No. (3), Encik Zulkifli.

     Encik Zulkifli bin Mohammed (Eunos GRC): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head Q be reduced by $10 in respect of Code QD 1500 of the Main Estimates.

    Sir, I shall not be speaking on the first amendment but I shall speak on my second cut which is on Civil Defence.

    Sir, the main aim of Civil Defence is to enhance the capability of our civilian population to survive any eventuality. Towards this end, extensive public education, training programmes and emergency exercises have been conducted over the past five to six years to provide opportunities for our people to learn how to cope with emergencies.

    Whilst I acknowledge that public participation in Civil Defence exercises has been good and encouraging, from my observation not many of our citizens are coming forward to volunteer as CD volunteers. In my view, Sir, this a cause for concern

Column: 573

since by now the Civil Defence message is familiar to all Singaporeans but yet the response to become CD volunteers is not up to expectation. Why is this so? I believe this could be attributable to public apathy and an insufficient pool of trained CD personnel and expertise. Therefore, a review in this area may be in order. In particular, I would like to know what steps are being taken to increase the present core of CD regular officers and staff.

    Sir, I am of the opinion that a more active recruitment programme must be undertaken since it is in our long-term interest to see more citizens, especially the younger generation, involved in Civil Defence activities. In this respect, could the Minister tell the House what new plans are being contemplated, firstly, to reach out to schools in order to stress upon students the importance of civil defence to civilians; secondly, to further assist the Civil Defence Coordinating Committees (CDCCs) play their roles at constituency level; and thirdly, to increase the pool of CD reservists?

    Regarding the CD reservists, perhaps the Ministry should consider expanding their role and scope so as to put their expertise to optimum use.

    Sir, I beg to move.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Sir, I am not as pessimistic as the Member over the state of affairs of CD volunteers because the proper perspective is to view it as a long haul. We are unlike Japan or some other countries which are so prone to natural disasters or a threat of a natural disaster is always hanging above one's head that it is easier to get people worked up and enthusiastic about civil defence. In our case, fortunately, the threat of typhoons or tidal waves or earthquakes is not there. Therefore, it is all the more difficult to arouse not only an awareness but a sufficient awareness that one wants to be involved in community civil defence work at the constituency level.

    Given that perspective, I think what has been achieved within the past few years in promoting civil defence as a concept and

Column: 574

arousing civil defence awareness - be prepared for the worst but hope for the best - is something that we can derive satisfaction from.

    Under the National Civil Defence Plan, the Civil Defence Volunteer Scheme was launched in 1982. Since then, the number of CD volunteers has increased. In December 1989 it was 29,750; in other words, about 80% of our targeted strength, and we hope to reach the targeted strength of 38,000 by 1992. Many of them comprise housewives, senior citizens, workers and students who have attended various training programmes. To get more people involved in the Civil Defence Volunteer Scheme at the constituency level, we think there must be a mix. It cannot be all work and no play or all work and no fun. There has to be the required time and input on operational matters, training, exercises. But in the long run, the constituency civil defence unit must also emerge as it is emerging as a grassroots organisation on its own stand. That is the only way that we can attract more people to join the civil defence units.

    What kind of other activities? We are already doing quite a lot, such as civic visits, sea training activities, weekend camps, shooting practices, competitions, telematches as well as overseas tours. These will provide a good balance to operational matters such as exercises, classes, training at the constituency level as well as exercises for several constituencies grouped together, including the recent Lavender MRT exercise. And I hope that CDCCs will work with other grassroots organisations and emerge as one of the family of constituency-based grassroots organisations.

    In addition to reservist rescue units at the zone level, since the Member asked about reservists, the SJCDF has recently introduced an assistant community relations officers programme which involves reservists in the planning and organising of civil defence programmes in constituencies. These reservists are chosen because of grassroots experience and the interest in community related work. Plans are indeed under way for more

Column: 575

reservists to be trained as assistant community relations officers.

    As for the other points, let me assure him that the SJCDF has borne in mind the points that he has made of reaching out to more people, including school students, to spread the message of civil defence. Since it is a long haul, we must continuously get new cycles of people to join the civil defence because civil defence preparedness may be called upon at a time when one may least expect it. It can be now, it can be five years' time or it can be 10 years' time. So we have to prepare on a long term basis.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, can I get a clarification from the Minister? I would like to ask the Minister who takes the lead in civil defence at the constituency level. And what kind of civil defence work is at the moment going on at Potong Pasir? As far as I know, I am not aware of any.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Sir, the existence of civil defence in the various constituencies is spearheaded by the Civil Defence in conjunction with existing grassroots organisations such as the CCC, the CCMC, together with their advisers.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, what about Potong Pasir? Can the Minister give some idea of what kind of civil defence is going on at Potong Pasir? I have no connections with the CCC or RC. I know that in other constituencies the MPs are automatically made advisers but I am not made an adviser to all these grassroots organisations. At least I think the Minister should let the MP for Potong Pasir know what is happening in regard to civil defence in that constituency.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Sir, there is a civil defence constituency unit in Potong Pasir.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: I am not aware of it.

     Prof. Jayakumar: He may not be aware of it, but there is, and I understand that it is quite active. He has raised the broader question which has been discussed in this House on several occasions as to why he is not appointed adviser to the various grassroots organisations. If he wants to raise that as a substantive issue, I think this is

Column: 576

not the appropriate place. He can file a question and we can discuss it all over again.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam (Fengshan): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head Q be reduced by $10 in respect of Code QE 1500 of the Main Estimates.

    Sir, I would like to speak on the emergency ambulance service. Yesterday, I brought up the problems involving the manning of the emergency ambulance service, ie, the problem of the nurses manning the service and the training of personnel from the ranks of the civil defence to form a core of paramedics.

    Today, I would like to focus on the services provided by our emergency ambulances. The crew of the ambulances are instructed to bring a patient to the nearest hospital. For this purpose, I understand Singapore is divided into six different zones. And depending on the zone that the patient is picked up from, he is sent to the hospital nearest his point of pick-up. This works out well for cases of traumatic injuries, eg, road traffic accidents. However, there are other emergencies which are of a non-traumatic nature. For example, if a patient has a medical problem being followed up at NUH turns ill at home, he may request to be sent to NUH even though his residential address may be at Bedok. The catchment zone of the patient, going by residential address, is not NUH, but his medical records are at NUH. Assuming that the patient is not critically ill but, nonetheless, ill enough for an ambulance to be called, it will make for better patient management if some flexibility is allowed into the system. Will the Minister comment on this?

    Sir, on a national basis, I also propose that it is time that we economised and rationalised our emergency ambulance service by including the private hospitals. Each private hospital maintains an accident and emergency unit and an ambulance service. However, for most of

Column: 577

us, in an emergency, it will be an almost reflex action for us to call for an ambulance by dialling 995 or even 999 in a panic situation. If an arrangement could be worked out with the private hospitals for less critical cases the patient could still call 995 and the call then redirected to the private hospital of the patient's choice. The ambulance from the private hospital could then attend to the patient, thus freeing our CD emergency ambulances to attend to the more urgent cases. Under present arrangements, the CD ambulance will not transport patients to a private hospital and this sometimes leads to ugly scenes, and more importantly, wastage of scarce resources.     The Government has three broad financial objectives. The first objective is to maintain a balanced budget over the long term. And by a balanced budget, I mean that the Government's recurrent and development expenditures should be financed from direct tax and indirect tax revenues. On the other hand, Government's expenditures are much more inelastic and tend to grow steadily year after year, reflecting annual wage increases and the increasing demand for public services. This means that when revenue collections are buoyant during good economic years, the budget will usually be in surplus. But when the economy slows, as during recession years, budget deficits will appear. When surpluses are realised, the Government's policy is to set aside part of the surpluses to cover possible future deficits in down years and to return the balance to the private sector through cuts in corporate, personal income taxes and assets taxes, and there have been many recent examples of such tax cuts.
